title-group.article-title: Recreating the Lost Object: Images of the Hand in "Sonata de otoño"

p.mixed-citation: Daniel E. Gulstad (26, 28-31)
Gerard Cox Flynn places on Satanism ("Adversary" 120-33)

Virginia Gibbs' Las Sonatas de Valle-Inclán: kitsch, sexualidad, satanismo, historia, whose title speaks for itself, and Rosco N. Tolman's Dominant Themes in the Sonatas of Valle-Inclán, which dedicates chapters to Donjuanism, religion, Satanism, death, and superstition. For a brief but usefully annotated bibliogra- phy, consult Leda Schiavo (26-30)
Juan Valera's Pepita Jiménez, in which Luis de Vargas exclaims, "¡Es tan distinguido, tan aristocático, tener una linda mano! Hasta se me figura, a veces, que tiene algo de simbóico" (189).
José Alberich (378)
Gerard Cox Flynn ("Bagatela" 135-41)
Robert Lima (56, 59, 64, 79)
Roberta L. Salper de Tortollá (15, 26)
Noël M. Valis ("Feminine" 359, 369), and especially Brad Epps (147-79)
Carlos Feal comprehensively extends the connec- tion between Bradomín and Valle-Inclán to works written after the Sonatas ("Bradomín" 43-44).
Gullón comments on this and other letters that appear in Otoño, concluding that "el contenido específico desaparece, sólo se alude al mensaje indirectamente [. . .]" (264-66).
Valle-Inchán of a letter-as-object rather than as a con- veyor of messages, see Ràfols (203-209)
Habra links Bradomín's "conciencia de escritu- ra" with Zorrilla's Don Juan Tenorio, which also opens with a love-letter motif (159)
("Feminine" 357)
Bradomín himself in Sonata de invierno, when he remarks that "si tenemos dos brazos es como un recuerdo de las edades salvajes [...]" (159)
George J. Young notes that "el fetiche más evidente en los cuentos de Valle-Inclán es el pelo, seguido por los ojos y luego las rosas" (121).
Ángel G. Loureiro views this as one of several representations of the symbolic battle between Christ and Satan (38).
Victor García Hoz 234)
(Ricoeur 93)
(Derrida 114)
Bradomin portrays Concha's hands as phantasmal (see 50, 87, 100)
"De nuevo levantó su mano, diáfana como mano de hada" (62)
La lámpara maravillosa: "Las sombras de las fábulas antiguas [...] levantan sus brazos entre la niebla de los mitos como espectros de nuestra conciencia [...]" (549)

La lámpara, Gonzalo Sobejano succinctly articulates the man- ner in which love and anguish combine to form beauty: "Los espectros de la conciencia [. . .] exponen figuralmente en la escena el eterno proceso de amor y dolor, generando un milagro de belleza" (227)
Otoño (54)
Invierno, where Bradomín's "dedos pálidos y ardientes deshojaban las margaritas que guardan el secreto de los corazones" (105)
"Entonces Concha había comprendido el misterio de aquel sueño [...]" (73)
Feal ("Realidad" 50-52)
Bradomín y Cristo: vida religiosa, amor ilícito, muerte" (40)
Barbey d'Aurevilly and, especially, Octave Mirbeau as likely sources for this scene, see Valis ("Refractions" 220-25)
Espronceda's El estudiante de Salamanca as yet another source, see Feal ("Realidad" 58)
Lavaud points out ("Un ejemplo" 596)
López confirms (78)
(Loureiro 41)
"¡Cuento de amor?," appears in July 1901
Hormigón (32, 111-15)
Gómez de la Serna (46- 54)
Madrid (55-61)
Speratti-Piñero (32)
Gonzalo Díaz-Migoyo characterizes Valle-Inclán's loss as a "mutilación como renacimiento" (41).
Epps, who reminds us that Bradomín's cupped hands are "the same hands that write his memoirs [. . .]" (165)
("Realidad" 51)
Bradomín's - who coincidentally sheds "dos lágrimas" after losing the hand in Invierno (158)
Bradomín reports feeling the weight - "como si fuese de plomo" - and pain of "la mano del brazo cercenado" (161, 163).
Valle-Inclán likewise reported feeling pain in his missing arm (see Gómez de la Serna 47).
V. S. Ramachandran notes that ghostly sensations are felt often in phantom limbs, and that it takes patients years or decades to accept the loss and to reshape the body image (22).
El Imparcial in 1914
Hormigón 232-33, 247
Lima 56-57)
